items.text: When I feel anxious, it colors everything I think about for the rest of the day.
items.rationale: Describes how emotional states influence cognitive processing and daily experience.

items.text: My mood has a powerful influence on the decisions I make.
items.rationale: Directly addresses the role of affect in shaping decision-making cognition.

items.text: I tend to react emotionally before I have time to think things through.
items.rationale: Captures the primacy of affective processing over deliberate cognition.

items.text: I am very aware of subtle shifts in my emotional state throughout the day.
items.rationale: Reflects emotional self-monitoring and affective awareness as a cognitive process.

items.text: When I'm in a good mood, I tend to see possibilities everywhere.
items.rationale: Illustrates mood-congruent cognitive appraisal and broadened attention under positive affect.

items.text: Feelings of guilt or shame can completely dominate my thinking.
items.rationale: Describes how self-conscious emotions hijack cognitive resources.

items.text: I find it hard to separate how I feel about something from what I think about it.
items.rationale: Captures the fusion of affective and cognitive appraisal processes.

items.text: She describes herself as someone whose emotions run deep and shape her worldview.
items.rationale: Third-person description of affect as a lens for interpreting the world.

items.text: I often experience a rush of feeling before I can identify what triggered it.
items.rationale: Reflects preconscious affective processing preceding cognitive identification.

items.text: My emotional memories are more vivid and accessible than factual ones.
items.rationale: Describes affect-enhanced memory encoding, a core affective-cognitive process.

items.text: When I'm sad, I interpret ambiguous situations more negatively.
items.rationale: Classic mood-congruent judgment bias in social-cognitive research.

items.text: I can physically feel my emotions in my body before I understand them mentally.
items.rationale: Somatic markers of affect preceding cognitive elaboration.

items.text: My enthusiasm for a project depends more on how I feel about it than on its objective merits.
items.rationale: Primarily affective motivation, but touches on behavioral engagement with tasks.

items.text: I notice that my feelings about a person strongly influence how I evaluate their arguments.
items.rationale: Affective halo effect in judgment, but involves interpersonal evaluation.

items.text: When someone upsets me, I can't stop replaying the interaction in my head.
items.rationale: Affective rumination triggered by an interpersonal event; could map to Interpersonal.

items.text: I tend to learn best by doing things rather than reading about them.
items.rationale: Describes a behavioral learning style emphasizing action over abstract cognition.

items.text: I set specific goals and track my progress toward them regularly.
items.rationale: Reflects self-regulatory behavior including goal-setting and monitoring.

items.text: My habits and routines shape my life more than my intentions do.
items.rationale: Captures the dominance of automatized behavioral patterns over deliberate cognition.

items.text: I believe that what people actually do matters more than what they say they believe.
items.rationale: Prioritizes observable behavior as the primary unit of understanding personality.

items.text: When I want to change something about myself, I focus on changing my actions first.
items.rationale: Behavioral self-regulation strategy emphasizing action over internal states.

items.text: He is the kind of person who jumps into action and figures things out along the way.
items.rationale: Third-person description of action-oriented behavioral style.

items.text: I notice that my daily behaviors often run on autopilot without much conscious thought.
items.rationale: Awareness of automatized behavioral scripts and habitual action patterns.

items.text: I judge my own success by what I've accomplished, not by how I felt doing it.
items.rationale: Behavioral outcome focus as the primary self-evaluation criterion.

items.text: Practicing a skill repeatedly is the most reliable way for me to master it.
items.rationale: Behavioral rehearsal and skill acquisition through repeated action.

items.text: I find that rewarding myself for completing tasks helps me stay motivated.
items.rationale: Self-administered reinforcement contingencies, a core behavioral self-regulation strategy.

items.text: I often use trial and error to solve problems rather than planning everything in advance.
items.rationale: Behavioral problem-solving approach emphasizing action over cognitive planning.

items.text: My past patterns of behavior are the best predictor of what I'll do in the future.
items.rationale: Reflects behavioral consistency and the predictive power of past actions.

items.text: I think people's characters are best revealed by their actions under pressure.
items.rationale: Primarily behavioral focus, but involves cognitive appraisal of character and situational context.

items.text: I've noticed that when I change my routine, my thinking patterns shift too.
items.rationale: Links behavioral change to cognitive change, straddling both domains.

items.text: I perform differently depending on whether I'm being watched by others.
items.rationale: Behavioral output changes due to social observation; could map to Interpersonal.

items.text: I spend a lot of time analyzing situations from multiple angles before making a decision.
items.rationale: Describes deliberate, multi-perspective cognitive processing in decision-making.

items.text: I am very aware of my own thinking patterns and can identify when my reasoning is biased.
items.rationale: Metacognitive awareness and self-monitoring of cognitive processes.

items.text: I tend to construct mental models of how things work before I interact with them.
items.rationale: Schema construction and mental simulation as core cognitive activities.

items.text: My beliefs and expectations strongly shape how I interpret new information.
items.rationale: Confirmation bias and schema-driven information processing.

items.text: I frequently engage in internal dialogue when working through a complex problem.
items.rationale: Inner speech as a cognitive tool for problem-solving and self-regulation.

items.text: She is someone who always wants to understand the 'why' behind everything.
items.rationale: Third-person description of causal reasoning and explanatory drive.

items.text: I often catch myself making assumptions and then deliberately question them.
items.rationale: Metacognitive monitoring and corrective reasoning processes.

items.text: I believe that how a person thinks about a situation matters more than the situation itself.
items.rationale: Reflects the cognitive appraisal principle central to social-cognitive theory.

items.text: I can usually identify the specific thought that led me to feel a certain way.
items.rationale: Cognitive self-awareness and the ability to trace affect back to cognition.

items.text: I rely heavily on mental categories and labels to organize my understanding of the world.
items.rationale: Categorical thinking and schema use as fundamental cognitive strategies.

items.text: When I encounter contradictory information, I feel compelled to resolve the inconsistency.
items.rationale: Cognitive dissonance resolution and need for cognitive consistency.

items.text: I often think about what I'm thinking about — my mind seems to have layers.
items.rationale: Metacognition and recursive self-reflective thought.

items.text: I notice that my self-talk can either motivate me or hold me back from taking action.
items.rationale: Cognitive self-regulation through self-talk, but references behavioral outcomes.

items.text: I tend to overthink social interactions and replay conversations in my mind.
items.rationale: Ruminative cognitive processing, but the content is interpersonal.

items.text: I find that changing my interpretation of a stressful event changes how I feel about it.
items.rationale: Cognitive reappraisal strategy, but the outcome is affective change; could map to Affective.

items.text: My physical surroundings have a major impact on my ability to concentrate.
items.rationale: Direct link between environmental conditions and cognitive functioning.

items.text: I think people are largely products of the circumstances they grew up in.
items.rationale: Endorsement of environmental determinism in personality development.

items.text: I notice that I think and act differently depending on the setting I'm in.
items.rationale: Situational variability in cognition and behavior, a core SCM environmental principle.

items.text: The culture I was raised in has shaped my deepest values and assumptions.
items.rationale: Cultural environment as a formative influence on cognitive schemas and values.

items.text: I am very sensitive to the atmosphere of a room — it immediately affects my state of mind.
items.rationale: Environmental cues directly influencing psychological state and cognitive processing.

items.text: He seems like a completely different person at work compared to when he's at home.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of cross-situational behavioral variability driven by context.

items.text: I believe that changing your environment is often the most effective way to change yourself.
items.rationale: Endorsement of environmental intervention as a mechanism for personal change.

items.text: Economic and social conditions have shaped who I am more than any personal choice.
items.rationale: Structural environmental factors as primary determinants of self-concept.

items.text: I find that I'm more creative in certain physical spaces than others.
items.rationale: Environmental affordances influencing cognitive performance and creativity.

items.text: Stressful environments make it nearly impossible for me to think clearly.
items.rationale: Environmental stressors impairing cognitive function.

items.text: I pay close attention to contextual cues when trying to understand why someone behaved a certain way.
items.rationale: Situational attribution style emphasizing environmental context in social judgment.

items.text: The opportunities and constraints in my life have mattered more than my talents.
items.rationale: Environmental opportunity structures as primary determinants of life outcomes.

items.text: I find that being in nature fundamentally shifts the way I process my thoughts.
items.rationale: Environmental influence on cognition, but could also reflect affective restoration.

items.text: The social norms of a group I'm in strongly influence what I think is acceptable.
items.rationale: Social environment shaping cognition, but overlaps with interpersonal influence.

items.text: I become a different version of myself depending on who I'm spending time with.
items.rationale: Contextual self-variation, but the context is interpersonal; could map to Interpersonal.

items.text: I naturally consider how my decisions will affect the people around me.
items.rationale: Other-oriented cognitive processing and social consideration in decision-making.

items.text: I am skilled at reading other people's intentions and motivations.
items.rationale: Social cognition and theory of mind applied to understanding others.

items.text: My sense of who I am is strongly shaped by my relationships with others.
items.rationale: Relational self-construal as a core interpersonal-cognitive process.

items.text: I often try to see things from another person's perspective before forming an opinion.
items.rationale: Cognitive perspective-taking as a fundamental interpersonal cognitive skill.

items.text: I think about how I come across to others more than most people do.
items.rationale: Self-presentational cognition and impression management awareness.

items.text: She has an uncanny ability to anticipate what others need before they ask.
items.rationale: Third-person description of advanced social-cognitive anticipation and empathic accuracy.

items.text: I learn a great deal about myself through my interactions with other people.
items.rationale: Reflected appraisal and interpersonal feedback as sources of self-knowledge.

items.text: I am very attuned to power dynamics and social hierarchies in any group.
items.rationale: Social-cognitive awareness of relational structures and status.

items.text: I frequently think about what kind of impression I'm making during conversations.
items.rationale: Self-monitoring and impression management cognition in social interaction.

items.text: Understanding other people's mental states is something I do almost automatically.
items.rationale: Automatized theory of mind and mentalizing as interpersonal cognition.

items.text: I tend to define my goals in terms of what I can contribute to others.
items.rationale: Communal goal orientation reflecting interpersonal values in self-regulation.

items.text: I am highly aware of unspoken social rules and expectations in any situation.
items.rationale: Social-cognitive sensitivity to implicit norms governing interpersonal conduct.

items.text: I find that my confidence depends heavily on the feedback I receive from others.
items.rationale: Interpersonal feedback shaping self-efficacy, but also touches on affective self-evaluation.

items.text: I adjust my communication style depending on who I'm talking to.
items.rationale: Interpersonal cognitive flexibility, but also involves behavioral adaptation.

items.text: Feeling rejected by someone changes the way I think about myself for days.
items.rationale: Interpersonal rejection affecting self-cognition, but the prolonged impact is strongly affective; could map to Affective.
